text: televised presidential debates began in
1960 when Vice President Richard Nixon
agreed to debate with his challenger
Senator John F Kennedy when John F
Kennedy the younger and less experienced
man sat casually in his chair with his
legs crossed and his hands folded while
Richard Nixon your vice president
desperately gripped the arm of his chair
and seemed uncomfortable the dynamics
between the two instantly shifted and at
that point the stakes were made clear
because we are in a deadly competition
to better known more seasoned candidate
had more to lose than gain by debating
his opponent because Kennedy fared so
well and may have defeated medicine on
the strength of that first debate but I
think it could be a greater country the
next three presidential elections there
were no debates at all was only in 1976
when the incumbent President Gerald Ford
was unlike today ttle president and his
challenger Jimmy Carter that debates
became a fixture in our electoral
process in Gerald Ford too would learn
the perils of debating his opponent
union because Gerald Ford at a puke a
moment of the Cold War seemed unaware
that a nation like Poland was actually a
satellite of the Soviet Union suddenly
it was Ford who didn't seem to have his
full of grasp of foreign politics as he
needed in 1984 one of the great issues
facing Reagan the incumbent was his age
a much younger opponent Walter Mondale
had been nominated by the Democrats
Reagan made what seemed an offhanded
joke that turned the tables on Monday I
will not make age an issue of this
campaign I am NOT going to exploit for
political purposes my opponents youth
and inexperience in 1992 when the
incumbent George HW Bush faced Bill
Clinton
there was a generational difference
between these two candidates and the
much younger Clinton seems more
energetic and engaged he was especially
strong at townhall meetings where he
took questions directly from the public
while George HW Bush seemed to hold them
in a distant small state for 12 years
I'll tell you how it's affected me in
the 2000 election one of the questions
facing George Bush the Republican
nominee was whether he had the seasoning
and judgment to hold the nation's
highest office but something George Bush
understood maybe better than Al Gore was
how the public watching the debate would
react to the comportment and demeanor of
the two candidates and Al Gore who was
very knowledgeable and a master of
policy got a little more aggressive with
George Bush than many viewers like but
can you get things done and I believe I
can when Barack Obama emerged in 2008 as
a Democratic nominee whose excitement
was generated in part by his youth when
he debated the much old as John McCain
there was a feeling among many viewers
that Senator McCain and was not showing
proper respect
you know who voted for it you might
never know that one you know modern
presidential debates are not really so
much about the candidates policies and
ideas as about their characters and
personalities and in a time when
campaigns are so carefully scripted the
televised debate is the unscripted
moment where maybe the real personality
or the character of the candidate shows
through
you
